title: Man Utd star Daniel James reveals he modelled his game on ex-Chelsea ace Eden Hazard
text:
Manchester United star Daniel James would learn from watching Eden Hazard as a youngster (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United new boy Daniel James has revealed how he tried to model his game on Eden Hazard when the Belgian was a Chelsea player.

In an otherwise disappointing start to the season, James has shone for the Red Devils, with three goals in nine appearances following his £15million move from Swansea City this summer.

It’s been a meteoric rise for James who only became a regular at Swansea last term and the Wales international admits he still can’t get over the fact he now plays for United.

‘I still don’t believe I’m a Manchester United player, it’s the stuff you dream of,’ James told BBC Sport.

James has scored three goals in his opening nine appearances for United (Picture: Getty)

‘Even though I’m in the changing room and I know I am, you still have to pinch yourself every night that you can say you’re a Manchester United player.

‘To play here is an honour that I’ll grasp every game. I’ve started better than I thought I would.

‘This club is amazing. Coming out at the Theatre of Dreams is unbelievable.

‘I’ll always love it and never get used to the sound of the fans. I want to be at the club my whole career.

‘When I see scarves or shirts, I think: “Why have they got my name on? They could have [Paul] Pogba or [Marcus] Rashford or [Jesse] Lingard.”

‘When people ask for pictures, I’ll think: “You don’t want one of me, you want one with them.”‘

James looked up to Hazard when the winger was at Chelsea (Picture: Getty)

James has lifted the lid on how, as a youngster at Swansea, he would learn from watching Hazard during the forward’s time in the Premier League.

‘The way Hazard was at Chelsea – his movement in behind, when to go and when to stay – he’s so quick, but the way he stops people and goes, and little one-twos, getting shots off quickly is something he’s done his whole career.

‘Getting in the box for tap-ins is something I need to improve on. When Hazard does a one-two you can’t get anywhere near him.

‘When I was younger, people said to me you won’t always be able to rely on speed. I used to just kick it past players and run – but nowadays that won’t happen, especially when people bank up on me.’
